Award.AwardTitle: Ethics in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project provides scholarships to support academically talented students with demonstrated financial need in attaining baccalaureate degrees in biology, computer information science, and mathematics at Gwynedd-Mercy College. In addition to scholarship aid, students are being supported through such activities as a living-learning community, modules and coaching on STEM study-skills, and peer tutoring. The project also features comprehensive training in ethics, leadership and decision making, seeking to graduate students imbued not only with the knowledge and competencies in STEM, but also sound ethical judgment. The intellectual merit of this project lies in the well-planned, literature-based activities to support student learning and success. The broader impacts include strengthening relationships with local schools and employers, as well as contributing to workforce needs, notably in bio- and information technology, in the Greater Philadelphia region. The focus on ethics education also serves as a model for similar institutions in the region and beyond.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For traditionally rigorous fields of study, such as those in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM), it is difficult to both attract students to the disciplines and to retain them.  Studies suggest that increased retention and academic improvement for academically promising students result from study skills development and supplemental social support programs.  More specifically, students in STEM majors can benefit from a combination of academic support, social or emotional support, and exposure to an interdisciplinary curriculum.  It has additionally been shown that a focus on ethics and dilemma-based problem solving in STEM fosters the analytical skills critical in those fields and increases awareness of ethical conflicts and an understanding of fairness and equality, characteristics are increasingly in demand for employers and society as a whole.   

In response to this evidence, the Ethics in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (E-STEM) program was developed to offer a modular approach for capacity development.  The goals of the project were to increase the number of students pursuing STEM fields, increase retention in STEM majors, and ensure more students enter the STEM workforce.  Additionally, the project aimed to determine whether training in ethics assisted with retention and employment. 

As a scholarship program, funding was designed to attract academically talented students to Gwynedd Mercy University's STEM programs:  Biology, Computer Information Science, and Mathematics.  The scholarships were accompanied by increased promotion and recruitment efforts.  Through 2018, the final year in which new scholarships were awarded, total applications were increasing; 2018 applications increased 21% over the previous year.  30.5% of E-STEM students indicated the E-STEM scholarship was a factor in either attending or continuing at GMercyU.  

Efforts related to retention were focused upon the formation of a STEM cohort supported by regular modular activities, including study skills, peer mentoring, social activities, and training in ethics, which is the novel component of this cohort model.  A living-learning community was established in the residence halls, with study space established for commuter student use, as well. 

Monthly study skills sessions focused upon a variety of standard topics, including note-taking, study habits, and testing, but also addressed topics such as presentation skills and relaxation techniques.  These modules resulted in the development of a series of study videos for future STEM students.  Peer mentoring provided additional support, both academically and emotionally, and provided leadership opportunities for the student mentors.  Mentoring modules also focused on team-building.  The social activities were designed as a time for games and competition.  They also involved visits from industry representatives and GMercyU STEM alumni.  These interactions exposed students to a variety of career options and employment opportunities.  Five students are now employed at compnies represented in these visits. 

The novel ethics component of the program was designed to provide students with the leadership, decision-making, and ethical framework that employers seek.  It also contributed to the strengthening of the cohort, central to establishing a feeling of community.  Monthly discussions ranged from generalized training in ethics and its importance, activities designed to help students develop their own ethical principles, the dissection of ethical scenarios, and the deconstruction of real-world scientific dilemmas, including authorship disputes, privacy, and data-sharing. 

All E-STEM graduates have graduated with a GPA >3.0.  95.7% of students completing the program to graduation are employed or in a graduate program; the one remaining student is a new graduate currently searching for employment.  Over half of the program graduates (56.5%) have entered a professional school or advanced degree program. 

Program outcomes are measured both qualitatively and quantitatively.  Data indicates the program has been effective in increasing ethical awareness; it also shows the cohort model benefitted participants.  Retention of E-STEM students is greater than the larger STEM enrollment.  Participant satisfaction is consistently high, with 100% indicating perceived value, especially in relation to the mentor-mentee relationship. 

 E-STEM graduates display statistically significant higher moral and ethical development scores than their comparative peers; it is evident from assessment measures the program promotes retention, employment preparedness, and self-reported value.  The E-STEM program has contributed to STEM workforce needs and impacted the integration of ethics in the STEM curriculum.  The ethics modules have also led to broader conversations among students, as they report continuing the discussions outside of the cohort. 

The E-STEM program has shown to provide high academic advantages at low operational cost and is a model that could be applied to many other academic programs.  The development of cohort identity has been crucial to increased academic achievement; the ethical discussions not only assisted with the development of that cohort, but also provided critical training for STEM majors in an area often not addressed during their education.  Numerous employers and graduate programs have indicated being impressed by this component of an E-STEM student?s education.  The strong focus on ethics education in the E-STEM program could serve as a model for other institutions.
